subject: Side effects of Glib
content:
A while ago I downloaded the Glib and GTK libraries because I thought I 
wanted to try my hand at developing applications in C.
I never did get around to actually using the libraries and I have since 
partially removed them from my hard drive.
However, ever since I built the libraries on my Ubuntu OS, I have been 
getting these weird debugging messages in my terminal every time I run 
programs from the command line.

When I run Chrome I get a lot of this guy:
[2060:2060:0626/001609:ERROR:omnibox_view_gtk.cc(431)] Not implemented 
reached in virtual void OmniboxViewGtk::ApplyCaretVisibility()

And whenever I run Sublime I get a lot of this guy:
GLib-GIO-Message: Using the 'memory' GSettings backend.  Your settings will 
not be saved or shared with other applications.

These messages, although interesting (as they provide some insight on what 
is going on in my OS), are beginning to overstay their welcome.
Anybody have experience with glib or C programming know how to turn this 
debugging output off?
html_content:
A while ago I downloaded the Glib and GTK libraries because I thought I wanted to try my hand at developing applications in C.
I never did get around to actually using the libraries and I have since partially removed them from my hard drive.
However, ever since I built the libraries on my Ubuntu OS, I have been getting these weird debugging messages in my terminal every time I run programs from the command line.

When I run Chrome I get a lot of this guy:
[2060:2060:0626/001609:ERROR:omnibox_view_gtk.cc(431)] Not implemented reached in virtual void OmniboxViewGtk::ApplyCaretVisibility()

And whenever I run Sublime I get a lot of this guy:
GLib-GIO-Message: Using the 'memory' GSettings backend.  Your settings will not be saved or shared with other applications.

These messages, although interesting (as they provide some insight on what is going on in my OS), are beginning to overstay their welcome.
Anybody have experience with glib or C programming know how to turn this debugging output off?

On Fri, Oct 20, 2017 at 11:24 PM, Geza Kovacs <gkovacs@stanford.edu> wrote:
Ah this was done in the context of desktop apps few years ago by morgan dixon when he was a PhD student, his system is called https://prefab.github.io/  Prefab https://digital.lib.washington.edu/researchworks/bitstream/handle/1773/33702/Dixon_washington_0250E_14470.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y

You can also implement the same technique on Android (it lets you paint over screens and monitor what's onscreen via the accessibility APIs), in fact the android version of habitlab https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.stanfordhci.habitlab does this to some extent.

ᐧ

2017-10-20 18:28 GMT-07:00 Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com>:
I would want it to be systemwide. This is something that I have previously called "augmented virtuality" and Kevin Kwok called "augmented reality for framebuffers"

There are a ton of awesome things you could do with this.

I wonder if my friend Geza, who works on a completely awesome program called habitlab https://habitlab.stanford.edu/ which sits between you and your addictive apps/websites does things like swap out Facebook with duolingo if you're on it too long, might actually have some ideas here.

As a side comment: there's something that terrifies me about the locked down nature of iPhones -- they prevent you from messing with the basic experience with using the device. This seems contrary to the message of apples famous 1984 ad, which champions the potential of computers as a way to empower people instead of empowering corporate overlords to control people.

subject: Re: How would I build a layer that sits between me and my computer?
content:
Atlas Recall is also worth checking out as it was kind of an API for APIs with the goal of “index[ing] all your information across many services", however they decided to call it quits after only a year. Perhaps due to the uneasiness of having a company be able to process everything you do on a digital device.

https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/18/atlas-informatics-calls-it-quits-after-less-than-a-year/

On Fri, Oct 20, 2017 at 6:44 PM, Andrey Fedorov <me@anfedorov.com> wrote:
On Mac, AppleScript is supposed to be a pretty powerful platform for what you're talking about, although I don't know how seriously macOS developers take their APIs for integrating with it. I imagine Keyboard Maestro is written in Objective-C, but would probably be better rewritten in Swift. It's probably more about knowing which API's to call rather than which language to use.

Windows has an accessibility layer which can serve for UI automation — a friend who integrated with it tells me it's pretty horrible — like interacting with a badly structured DOM, although it probably depends on the app.

Not sure about Android / iOS functionality & limitations, but agree the irony of 1984 ad is real. But back then Apple was tiny and IBM was huge. They would probably argue that if you want to make it better, you should go work for Apple ;)

subject: Re: How would I build a layer that sits between me and my computer?
content:
On Mac, AppleScript <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AppleScript> is supposed
to be a pretty powerful platform for what you're talking about, although I
don't know how seriously macOS developers take their APIs for integrating
with it. I imagine Keyboard Maestro is written in Objective-C, but would
probably be better rewritten in Swift. It's probably more about knowing
which API's to call rather than which language to use.

Windows has an accessibility layer which can serve for UI automation — a
friend who integrated with it tells me it's pretty horrible — like
interacting with a badly structured DOM, although it probably depends on
the app.

Not sure about Android / iOS functionality & limitations, but agree the
irony of 1984 ad is real. But back then Apple was tiny and IBM was huge.
They would probably argue that if you want to make it better, you should go
work for Apple ;)

On Fri, Oct 20, 2017 at 6:29 PM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

> Question: how do I build an application like keyboard maestro? What
> language?
>

On Mac, AppleScript is supposed to be a pretty powerful platform for what you're talking about, although I don't know how seriously macOS developers take their APIs for integrating with it. I imagine Keyboard Maestro is written in Objective-C, but would probably be better rewritten in Swift. It's probably more about knowing which API's to call rather than which language to use.

Windows has an accessibility layer which can serve for UI automation — a friend who integrated with it tells me it's pretty horrible — like interacting with a badly structured DOM, although it probably depends on the app.

Not sure about Android / iOS functionality & limitations, but agree the irony of 1984 ad is real. But back then Apple was tiny and IBM was huge. They would probably argue that if you want to make it better, you should go work for Apple ;)

subject: Re: How would I build a layer that sits between me and my computer?
content:
I would want it to be systemwide. This is something that I have previously
called "augmented virtuality" and Kevin Kwok called "augmented reality for
framebuffers"

There are a ton of awesome things you could do with this.

I wonder if my friend Geza, who works on a completely awesome program
called habitlab https://habitlab.stanford.edu/ which sits between you and
your addictive apps/websites does things like swap out Facebook with
duolingo if you're on it too long, might actually have some ideas here.

As a side comment: there's something that terrifies me about the locked
down nature of iPhones -- they prevent you from messing with the basic
experience with using the device. This seems contrary to the message of
apples famous 1984 ad, which champions the potential of computers as a way
to empower people instead of empowering corporate overlords to control
people.

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:31 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
WOW.

When you stretch it, do you always stretch it the same way or do you alternate between the two ways?

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 9:09 AM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
Smale horseshow is the attractor set of a dynamical map on the unit square. The image in your head is that of a taffy machine. You stretch the unit square by a factor >2 one axis of the square, and then compress in the other axis by that same factor, getting a long rectangle. Then, you fold the resulting rectangle back onto the square. Do that until you get to an attractor in the phase space.

The restriction is that the trajectories in the phase space of the thing cannot cross. That seems like it would admit to a computational simplification (lower computational complexity) for the inverse mapping.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 8:59 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Great explanation of the Cantor Set, I got lost when we started talking about the horseshoe.

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:23 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:17 PM, Nikhil Buduma <nkbuduma@gmail.com> wrote:
Yeah same can someone translate? Tried Wikipedia bashing with little avail

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 5:46 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
WOW this went way over my head.

On Sun, Jun 7, 2015 at 4:20 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee

html_content:
Smale horseshow is the attractor set of a dynamical map on the unit square. The image in your head is that of a taffy machine. You stretch the unit square by a factor >2 one axis of the square, and then compress in the other axis by that same factor, getting a long rectangle. Then, you fold the resulting rectangle back onto the square. Do that until you get to an attractor in the phase space.

The restriction is that the trajectories in the phase space of the thing cannot cross. That seems like it would admit to a computational simplification (lower computational complexity) for the inverse mapping.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Wed, Jun 10, 2015 at 8:59 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Great explanation of the Cantor Set, I got lost when we started talking about the horseshoe.

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:23 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

On Tue, Jun 9, 2015 at 8:17 PM, Nikhil Buduma <nkbuduma@gmail.com> wrote:

WOW this went way over my head.

On Sun, Jun 7, 2015 at 4:20 PM H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
So you can get a Cantor set by cutting the classical Smale horseshoe through the middle. Is there any body of statistical work which attempts the inverse problem: that is, looking at some fractal, getting the corresponding chaotic map? I'm aware of the symbolic dynamics literature and the IFS work, but I'm thinking topological stuff like the classic Smale horseshoe specifically.

Best,
Howon Lee

OK, so you know what the Cantor set is, it's the fractal defined on the support [0,1] such that anything which is represented in the trinary representation in the 2 is not a member of the set. Meaning, take out the middle third of the support [0,1], take out the middle third of the 2/3 remaining, and so on.

An alternate and nontrivial construction is to cut out the middle of Smale's horseshoe.

There's a lot of statistical work done on the inverse fractal problem, much of it pretty amazingly useless. M Barnsley's group invented the inverse IFS learning algorithm for this thing called fractal compression, which after being featured on Microsoft Encarta 1998 never got use in real places again.

But that stuff depends upon the operation of affine transforms (it searches parameter space in a non-terrible time because it assumes that the fractal is generated from an affine iterative transform). Smale's horseshoe is based on topologically different transforms, but it's still a limited set of them, so they should be, if not feasible for search, at least amenable to MCMC or something.

Best,
Howon Lee

subject: UI/UX Project Interest
content:
Greetings Hacksphere,

I work for a small managed WordPress hosting company. We are developing a
platform, which is already largely developed.

Our team is interested in some UI/UX project assistance. We are currently
going through some internal design processes.

I thought it would be interesting to reach out to Hacksphere and see what's
out there. We are interested in hourly contract proposals with individuals
or small teams.

Please feel free to email me personally with recommendations or any
questions. We can have a meeting and go over any questions or details.

The requirements for the frontend of the platform are slim. We require a
suite of CRUD elements including permission management and some advanced
features in the future. We are looking at React and JQuery + Bootstrap
stacks.

Thank you very much,
JP Hayes
html_content:
Greetings Hacksphere,

I work for a small managed WordPress hosting company. We are developing a platform, which is already largely developed.

Our team is interested in some UI/UX project assistance. We are currently going through some internal design processes.

I thought it would be interesting to reach out to Hacksphere and see what's out there. We are interested in hourly contract proposals with individuals or small teams.

Please feel free to email me personally with recommendations or any questions. We can have a meeting and go over any questions or details.

The requirements for the frontend of the platform are slim. We require a suite of CRUD elements including permission management and some advanced features in the future. We are looking at React and JQuery + Bootstrap stacks.

Thank you very much,
JP Hayes

subject:
Re: Can you explain to a smart 10 year old why the volume of a cone
 is PI*r^2*h/3?
content:
In one dimension, it takes two little sticks to make a big stick.

In two dimensions, it takes four little triangles to make a square.

In three dimensions, it takes six pyramids to make a cube.

In four dimensions, it takes eight hyper-pyramids to make a hyper-cube.

subject: Can you explain to a smart 10 year old why the volume of a cone is PI*r^2*h/3?
content:
Hint: Integration is *not *a satisfactory answer.

If you can't, you'll benefit from reading this intuitive, illustrated,
5-minute explanation <http://thinkzone.wlonk.com/Area/AreaVol.htm> of all
the area and volume formulas that we were forced to memorize.

-- Rafa

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael's Schedule<https://www.google.com/calendar/embed?src=2nmlils4ct1gmcbaua44fcq228%40group.calendar.google.com&src=1lq7cdo21rlghjpt4qv3r4k7b4%40group.calendar.google.com&amp&ctz=America/Los_Angeles&mode=week&src=qtlkpodctr50n9mldht46sjmvk%40group.calendar.google.com&src=rafaelcosman%40gmail.com&ctz=America/Los_Angeles&amp&title=Rafael's%20Schedule>

If you can't, you'll benefit from reading this intuitive, illustrated, 5-minute explanation of all the area and volume formulas that we were forced to memorize.

-- Rafa

On Wed, Nov 6, 2013 at 11:14 PM, chris gervang <chrisgervang@gmail.com> wrote:
Recently my .tk domains have been non-responsive. Jacob, do you renew all of these domains every 4 months? Or do they work without maintenance?

.Chris Gervang
From: Jacob Cole
Sent: ‎11/‎4/‎2013 8:18 PM
To: HackSphere@googlegroups.com

Subject: Re: My .tk domailns

I'd say they are as meaningful as any and really convenient.
Bit.ly's are uglier URLs that are less memorable.
Maybe I should make subdomains instead? But those are less memorable too.

One big thing I wish is that there were an auto-updated public list of the domains I shared. As an interim step I put a list of them on my minimalist homepage, http://jacobsstuffmin.tk/ (though I'm not sure they ultimately belong there).

More generally, I ultimately think it's just way too difficult for people to create content on the web right now, even with such innovations as Google Sites. I wish I could just quickly make a bunch of Google documents with reasonable URLs and link them to each other in a coherent way.

subject: RE: My .tk domailns
content:
Recently my .tk domains have been non-responsive. Jacob, do you renew all of these domains every 4 months? Or do they work without maintenance?

.Chris Gervang

-----Original Message-----
From: "Jacob Cole" <tmad4000@gmail.com>
Sent: ‎11/‎4/‎2013 8:18 PM
To: "HackSphere@googlegroups.com" <HackSphere@googlegroups.com>
Subject: Re: My .tk domailns

I'd say they are as meaningful as any and really convenient.
Bit.ly's are uglier URLs that are less memorable.
Maybe I should make subdomains instead? But those are less memorable too.


One big thing I wish is that there were an auto-updated public list of the domains I shared. As an interim step I put a list of them on my minimalist homepage, http://jacobsstuffmin.tk/ (though I'm not sure they ultimately belong there).


More generally, I ultimately think it's just way too difficult for people to create content on the web right now, even with such innovations as Google Sites. I wish I could just quickly make a bunch of Google documents with reasonable URLs and link them to each other in a coherent way.





On Tue, Nov 5, 2013 at 3:31 AM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:

Wow. I genuinely don't know. They are free and easy to get. Can you point to a specific alternative?


-- R

What is the point of .tk domains? Why not meaningful domains? Or URL shorteners? Or URL shorteners with meaningful keys?
—
Sent from Mailbox for iPhone
